155321112212111111111.content:
Years pass, and many that remembered when Kamper’s Castle wasn’t there were long dead. Even the Sparta Princess that he had once saved was now long dead and buried, although the story of Kamper was passed on. Little by little, and age by age, people started making pilgrimages to the great golden doors of Kamper’s Castle, as well as the shrine at the top of the mountain. A narrow staircase had been erected for the less sturdy to ascend the mountain. Although the trip was still a day or so journey to the top, and more than a few had fallen off the narrow stairs to the top, falling to their death. Kamper people generally walked amoung the realms of men, except Sparta, and observe them. After that he would go to his castle and continue training, make more additions to his castle or its features, or just observe those trying to unravel the secrets of his shrine. The only time he interfered in this was when a few of them had made an alter to him, which he soundly destroyed and boomed out his displeasure at being worshiped. Although, after that display, it only escalated the worship in the cities. Some of the age’s scholars would get as far as his name, watching how his symbol glowed as they said it, but that was about it as far as people getting into his castle. Eventually, he got sick of it and decided to go to the main temple they made for him, which was rich with many treasures and inaccurate descriptions, and set them straight.

He arrived in his sealed form, looking up to the replicas of his golden doors to his castle. They hadn’t spared any expense in recreating them… minus Kamper’s enchantments and reinforcements of course. They were currently open and people were flooding in and out of the massive doors. Kamper was silently glad he hadn’t opened his doors to this extent, he could only imagine how many people would flood the place if he did so. He walked passed a 200 foot statue that was their best replica of his image that was found on the walls of his shrine. He had to admit, it wasn’t horrible. The grand hall, right after the doors, was as huge as the doors were, but etched and painted with an exact replica of his shrine, again without the enchantments and fortifications. However, unlike his shrine, there were venders of different kinds on both sides of the main walkway. Most of them trying to pawn off of his name to sell things. ‘Death’s chosen knife blades’, ‘Cloaks worth of Death’, and so on. At the back was another door that was currently open, where the door to your Castle would be up at the shrine, but this one was smaller and open. He took a step inside and it seemed like he was stepping into an altered slaughter house. There was a very large alter at the back, with different stations beforehand that dealt with preparing both the people and the animals for worship. There were sections were people would cut themselves, other stations where they could wash themselves and their sacrifices. Even a chart where they could see what their sacrifice level would please ‘Death’ or so the Chart said. He looked at it and the dozens of stations and was angered by what he saw. At the bottom were the standard things of sacrifice; sheep, cows, pigs, birds, and that sort of thing. But it got progressively worse, at the top, even after mythical beings and animals, were the worshiper’s first born.

“Welcome, pilgrim, what has brought you to the temple of the most powerful god of all Greece?” One of the Priest asked Kamper as he made his rounds. He seemed approachable, but also slightly arrogant and vain. Thinking that he was part of some elite club. But his comment only infuriated him more. Kamper was and is a Titan that punished would be gods. He NEVER wanted to be perceived as one. How these people had got him so messed up was beyond him, but he couldn’t lose his temper… yet.

“Tell me about him?” Kamper asked, hiding his distain well.

“Oh, a new worshiper!” He exclaimed, which got a round of clapping before they all went about their business. “Death is the most powerful of all the gods. After all, even the mighty Zeus fears dying. It is for that reason we worship him. In doing so, we can earn his favor and not only extend our own lives, but shorten those of our enemies.” He started. He then went on preaching to Kamper about what was ensured and required for ‘Death’s favor’, as usual, sacrifices of blood was the highest sacrifice in each category, but they also could be appeased with mass amounts of gold or land. This temple, being the starting point, was the biggest and most accurate replica of Kamper’s own shrine. “So, what do you think?”

“I think…” Kamper started, looking around then back at the priest, very angry…especially about the infant sacrifices that he had just heard about. “… it is revolting! GET OUT!!!”

The last part was in a very loud and ominous voice that also had its own power. It lifted everyone and every living thing, except the now entering Pride and the priests, out the doors , then sealed them shut. Before anyone, including the priest that was talking to him, could get a good look at him, he changed to his released form, Death. With a flick of the wrist he sent all the priests to one side of the room and another rendered all the instruments in the room and gathered gold to ash. The priests were in horrified shock by this, but then looked to see Pride landing on a statue of Death, right above them. Unlike Kamper or Death, Pride was seen all too often and was well known to be Death’s.

“Never, in all my years have I ever been so insulted.” Death said in his low and ominous voice, static discharges and flames erupting around the room at his mere presence. “WHERE do you get the idea that I am a god or need, much less want, sacrifices… EXPECIALLY CHILDREN!!!?!???”

“My…” Started whom appeared to be the high priest. He had cuts up and down his arms and face, probably in other parts of his body.

“SILENCE!” Boomed Death as he, with no movement, rose the high priest off his knee and feet so he was floating above the rest of them. “I have written carefully worded history and instructions in the shrine at the top of my mountain, so this sort of thing does NOT happen. You get a few words right and you assume you know enough to start a temple in my name. If you had actually bothered learning what I actually wrote, you would know that this whole thing…” Kamper continued as he ripped off the huge tablet off the wall and hovered it so they could see it, then slowly began turning it to ash as he had with the gold in the room “… is unbelievably revolting.”

At this point, even people outside could tell that something was up, as they could sometimes hear him, the pressure around them was increasing, and black clouds began to form above the temple and spreading over the city. They could easily see, that Death was NOT happy. Some began running, thinking that the temple and all those around it would experience Death’s wrath.

“Let me make this, absolutely clear. I am not a god, I do not wish to be worshipped, I am disgusted at the thought of any sacrifice of life on my account, If you wish to continue then you must finish reading my shrine, and…” Death listed off then raised them all above the ground, making them listen intently to what he had to say. “… if I ever see you all take innocent life on my account again, I will destroy you all in the longest and most painful way possible. Is that understood???”

“My…” Started the high priest said again, before he was cut off by another increase of Death’s power.

“I care not for your excessive brown nosing. A simple yes or no will suffice. Do you understand???” Death explained and repeated.

“Y-yes!” They all said at once. At that moment, he turned into the shadow of the room and most of his powers left the area, doors opening as well. Death disappeared from their view and Pride flew out the open doors and, to the crowd’s amazement, flew majestically into the distance, amidst the dispersing black clouds, producing some effects of his own.
155321112212111111111.title: Years pass...

1553211122121111111112.content:
Death was not particularly happy with man for a while. Making him into a god and doing such horrid things in his name… But he noticed that a new wave of worship followed in his wake, after he had appeared before them and corrected them. They hadn’t stopped worshipping him, but they had stopped the sacrificing of life. That, and they started to work hard in translating the walls of his shrine. Many made pilgrimages to his shrine to make sure the temples were accurate and sometimes to test words to the symbols on the wall. He was not known as a god anymore, but a Titan. Regardless of the accuracy of the statement, he wasn’t thrilled that it made him more of a villain than anything. After all, Titans in this realm were, at best, troublemakers. Every once in a while, a god would walk with him, as he wondered the earth.

“Why do you insist on walking among men? You are only going to see first hand how crude and simple they are. What you saw in your temple… that is the sort of thing they escalate to every few decades.” Artemis asked, not understanding why Zeus’ offer to house him at Mount Olympus didn’t interest him. After all, one could potentially see all of the world in any detail one wished from up there.

“I do not wish to be some all powerful deity that judges from on high. I want to be among the people, and actually living in the world. Sure, some of them… most of them are not any sort of equal to me. But there is one group of people that are always better than I am, or you for that matter.” Kamper said as he walked. Artemis was hidden as well in a common but still a little more high profile commoner getup.

“And what group would that be?” Artemis asked, wondering what being she had been blind to that could best Kamper/Death… and the gods… with their new weapons.

“Them…” Kamper responded as he pointed to some innocent children.

“Mortal children???” She asked, unbelieving.

“Indeed. Name one being in creation that is as pure, trusting, loving, energetic, and a host of other POSTIVE characters that is higher than a child. I dare say, you will find it a fruitless pursuit to find such a creature.” Kamper explained. “For this reason, I do not give up on man. There is the rare adult person that is pleasant to be around. I get to live among them and experience, possibly even help them when I can get away with it.”

“That must be nice, being able to look at them like that. While we just rule over them from Olympus…” She accepted, but was still having a hard time believing. After all, the common perception of power was that the one that had the most of it was the one that was better than everyone else. But she at least knew how Kamper/Death viewed things a little better.

“Miss… Here you go! You are really pretty!” said a young girl that had picked a flower and given it to Artemis. Rather than explain it, Kamper just let her experience it. There was no way the little one knew who she was. It was an innocent gesture to her, regardless who she was, just because… Artemis was unable to voice words but smiled to the little one before she went off playing with the other kids again. Kamper watched as he saw her treasure the small flower. The flower was nothing special, hundreds of thousands of them grew and were cut down in the fields around them all the time. But she looked to treasure this one.

“I need to go!” She suddenly said and disappeared when she was certain that none of the people around were looking. Even if they were currently allowed to effect the world of men, the gods were beginning to limit that interaction, per Zeus’s orders. Kamper suspected that Artemis’s sudden exit was probably because a mortal had affected her in a way that she would want to be more open. Kamper also suspected that she would use her powers as a god to reward the young girl, and maybe watch over her.
1553211122121111111112.title: Kamper continues to walk the Earth.

15532111221211111111121.content:
“In the name of the King of Sparta, open this door!” came a command as some Spartans tried to get the door to Death’s shrine open.

Many had tried to crack the door open in different ways, but only the gods had been able to get in by translating the shrine correctly. Kamper had been watching them for a while, ever since they had come out of Sparta and came to his shrine. It was no secret to most that knew Kamper/Death, mainly the gods, that Sparta held his respect. It was the only place he would not go, on order from the King that had died some time ago, so Kamper transformed into Death and had Pride fly in to a spot where he could perch and be reached by normal sized mortals. However, Pride was more than powerful enough to screech at his arrival and force the Spartans back with merely the sonic burst from his screech and landing. One of them, that looked like the new King, came forward slowly to retrieve the message.

‘For what purpose do you wish to enter my domain?’ The letter wrote. The young man straightened before speaking, but to the door, rather than to Pride.

“My Grandmother said, before she died, that she knew you and that it would be best for Sparta if I would open communications with you. SHE said that, even if you are a god, you have obeyed her father’s ban of you in our kingdom, and that lifting it would be something you would want…” He said, a little confusion but also pleading in his voice.

Kamper was still not thrilled by having the ‘god’ title, but he agreed, access to Sparta was something that he more than desired. To this, he opened the door to his castle and made a passage directly to the throne room by sealing all other doors and passages, but leaving observing points so they could look around as they traveled. They looked at the open doors wearily, but not out of fear. Spartans, after all, weren’t known for their fear. Pride took off, and flew slowly as if to guide them, to which they followed.

“This… can’t be possible…” Stated a few of the men as they walked along the colossal walkways and passages.

They were unconcerned when the doors behind them closed, more excited actually. But they were not ready for the sheer magnitude of the place, as well as the value of the very ground they walked on. Even for a warrior society like theirs, they knew the value of so much gold around them. They eventually made it to the throne room, to which Pride flew over to Death and perched near his throne, a spot that seemed made just for him. He resonated with Death, making black flames erupt out of his wings and Death’s body to an extent, before settling in.

“Your Grandmother and her Father’s name may have gotten me to open the doors, but that doesn’t mean you have the same authority. For what reason do you want me present in Sparta?” Death asked. He could’ve just ready their minds, but he preferred with his favorite people in this realm to have them answer themselves.

“Don’t you know already? The things they say about you in your temple makes you seem all knowledgeable…” The King stated.

“I have admired Sparta for some time. Due in no small part to its reputation and the attitude I witnessed by your Grandmother and her Father. I have a certain respect for Sparta… I am capable or reading your minds and those of every subject you have… I choose not to out of my respect for your country. Do not confuse it with ignorance.” Death replied.

“We… are fighting a war. Something, I am sure, you are not surprised in. However, this new enemy is not or mortal men. They are a variety of creatures, some easily handled, and some that decimate men and land alike. Even our soldiers are helpless against them to a point. It seems like the other gods do no help like they do with other parts of Greece. Even the great god Ares hasn’t rendered us aid…” The King answered, again, not scared but more concerned for his Country.

“That is because they are letting man handle their own problems. But since I have taken a particular interest in Sparta, they have left me as your champion. The beasts you speak of see that you have banned me from Sparta and see that leaves it without a protector, opening the doors for them to attack more boldly. Possibly spurred on by the titans.” Death answered as if informing them of the weather.

“Will you help us, and be our Champion then?” The King asked, more formally.

“Did you not hear what I said? I AM your Champion. But that binds me to your banishment of me. If you don’t want me in your Country, then I will not set foot inside it, as I have done. Not to say that I haven’t helped any and all Spartan forces that came out of the boundaries of Sparta, like your dear Grandmother. I believe I saved her from a Hydra at one point.” Death answered.

“So… the only thing I would need to do… is welcome you back into Sparta???” He asked.

“Yes.” Death answered simply.

“Then I wish to do so.” He replied.

“State your name.” Death stated as he stood, making the area around him and them shake with his power. After all, it was hard to hold back in his released form. He seemed to float down until his 10 foot form was a mere 20 feet away from the Spartan King and his few soldiers.

“I am King Leonidas of Sparta!” He declared, obviously very proud of the Sparta part more than his rank. This Death liked most about him… in a way.

“King Leonidas, do you give me permission to enter and do as I will in your domain until the end of time?” Death asked simply, but there was obvious power behind his words. It could almost be felt around them, centering with Death and the young King. His next words would obviously make something happen, one way or another.

“I do, as King of Sparta. I, King Leonidas give you entry to do as you will in Sparta from now till the end of time!” he declared and repeated, to be clear.

From that point there was a bit of energy that became material and floated around the room then plunged itself into the young King’s chest, driving him back and staggering him a little. Before he could accuse or ask what it was, Death started explaining.

“I am now bound to your bloodline. As long as it exists, I will render aid and protect you and what you require me to protect, within reason. Your oath will be magically sealed by your blood, and by all those after you. This bond will give you the strength of many men, and me access to Sparta whenever and however I chose. This is our pact. Now, as for this threat you are so worried about…” Death stated and slammed a foot down, instantly transporting all the people in the room to a field in the direct center of Sparta. They all looked around and instantly knew where they were, it was also right beside a temple of his, to which he turned to ash to their astonishment. “… I am not a god, nor do I require worship. My doors will always open to the King and his descendents. As for them…”

Death looked over and saw a giant naga closing in on the city behind them. Death raised his hand and the giant creature rose off the ground as well. He gave his hand a flick and it was burst into black flames before the wind carried the reduced ashes away. After that, he slammed his exposed hand into the ground and a sort of magical barrier spread from his location until it encompassed all of Sparta with all its land and people.

“While inside the confines of Sparta, your people will not suffer harm from what is unnatural. In the affairs of man, I trust Sparta can handle itself.” Death stated then whistled loudly to which Pride came down. “He will keep an ever constant eye on this domain and alert me if I need to be present. The only other person that can call me is YOU, Leonidas, King of Sparta.”

“Thank you… What should I call you and how do I call for you?” The young King asked.

“By my name, Death. As for how to contact me… you must say my chosen password, which only you will be able to say, and those of your bloodline. Anyone else will become tongue tied when trying. The phrase is, ‘You’ve knocked on Death’s door, now Death is knocking back.’ That will be a phrase to summon me in emergencies. Do not use it otherwise. In less emergency situations, tell Pride contact me. He will in a manner of hours.” Death responded then began to fade into the growing shadow of the sunset. “Live well, King Leonidas.”

As Death faded and melded with the shadows around them, they were still trying to process what had just happened. One thing was for sure, Kamper/Death would be spending a lot more time in Sparta, finally…
15532111221211111111121.title: Patching things up with Sparta

155321112212111111111211.content:
Kamper, once again, walked around among men. But this time he was visiting Sparta for the first time since he was invited back. He dared not come back when he was banned, but now that he was allowed to roam free as he desired and as long as he wanted, he freely walked through the country and in the cities. He saw that they had NOT rebuilt his temple and they earned a bunch of points for that. The other countries had only escalated his worship after his instruction, although the sacrificing of innocent children and people were no longer tolerated. It was nice to give instruction and they actually follow it. Kamper casually walked through the capital City and once again observed some of the Spartan soldiers training.

“Hey, you!” Yelled one of the men training, or looked more like an instructor of sorts.

He was pointing to Kamper, who had taken to sitting on a wall, observing them train with a general interest. After all, Spartans training, while brutal, was much more entertaining than any other army of man.

“What do you think you are doing?” He demanded as he came near Kamper, to which Kamper simply looked down at him from his perch.

“Watching Spartans train.” Kamper responded, as if it was obvious.

“And why are you doing that?” He asked.

“Because it is pleasing to watch.” Kamper responded.

“Well, you definitely aren’t a Spartan, from the look of you. That means you must be a slave of some kind.” He said with an amount of certainty.

“Nope, just an ally, hopefully a friend of sorts.” Kamper responded.

“Friend!...” He blared out, making him and the others laugh loudly at the fact. “You want to come down here and see how worthy of friendship you are?”

“Ok.” Kamper responded. He then pushed himself off the wall and landed on the ground. Some of the laughing stopped, as the drop was about 20 feet. Not enough to be awe inspiring, but enough to impress some. They were more fascinated by the fact that this apparent new comer was not backing down to the fighting skill of an obviously well trained Spartan. He walked passed the Spartan in question and into the training circle. Then turned and waited casually for the Spartan to approach.

“So, you wish to die?” He more stated then asked as he adjusted his shield and spear. Unlike most other armies, Spartans sometimes, depending what level they were at, trained with real weapons rather than wooden ones. Again, some of the observing Spartans started laughing at Kamper’s apparent idiocy at accepting a match against a Spartan of any rank, much more their superior.

“Does it matter?” Kamper asked as he drew his sword and stood at a relaxed position.

“I suppose not.” The offending Spartan said then started the match by walking forward and thrusting his spear at his shoulder.

He was obviously thought that he could end it quickly by piercing a shoulder, without killing a potential ally of Sparta. But it was not in Sparta’s nature to suffer fools. So, this would be the only mercy shot he would give. Kamper, on the other hand was no novice, even in his current sealed form. He was still more powerful than most of the gods in this form, not to mention his Death sword was not one to be trifled with. So Kamper easily dodged his thrust and started to spar. It was like a dance to him. The Spartan would attack, followed by a close evasion, followed by Kamper moving to a blind spot and doing something; like kicking him in the backside, or pushing his shoulder so that the spear or shield went into the dirt. However, while such an action would’ve rendered the weapon unusable to most, Spartans had enough experience and strength to forcibly pull the buried weapon out of the ground and continue the match.

Kamper also knew that destroying the shield like he had done to other Greek warriors would not be a good move to do to a Spartan. A Spartan had a certain connection to his shield. One that Kamper had no desire to take away. So he simply played this game with him for a staggering 4 hours, amazed at this mortal’s ability to keep going. Then again, he was a Spartan, so it was half expected.

“Are you ever going to attack?!?” Yelled the Spartan, frustrated that he was being out maneuvered so easily.

“Not when you are doing such a good job of it yourself. All I have to do is evade until you run out of energy, then I win.” Kamper answered, as if it was obvious.

At this point there was a crowd watching. Whomever this was, it was someone of great standing in Sparta, because no one dared laugh or smile at his progress in this match.

“Then why are you fighting?” Asked one of the bystanders. The Spartan that was fighting looked to whom it was, then righted himself and bowed as King Leonidas was there, observing.


“I was gauging a Spartan’s fighting strength.” Kamper responded. “I’m impressed…”

“And who are you to gauge such a thing?’’ The King asked.

“Who do you think?” Kamper responded then pointed at a bit of ground at his feet. He looked down and Kamper made some black flames appear and cast his symbol on the ground, then disappear when he saw the King realize who he was. He almost bowed, but Kamper shook his head to stop him. “If it pleases the King, I would like to walk among your people and dwell here for a while.”

“Yes! Yes of course!” The King agreed. Now knowing who he was talking to, he also seemed to understand that Kamper didn’t want his presence overly known, but was far from hiding either. Therefore he didn’t make a decree for them all to bow to him. “You may dwell in Sparta for as long as you wish. Maybe teach us a thing or two?”

“If that is your wish, my King.” Kamper said, and bowed to him. This seemed to shock him and make him gulp at the same time. For someone of Kamper/Death’s stature to bow to him was both exhilarating and humbling at the same time.
155321112212111111111211.title: Hanging with the Spartans!!!

1553211122121111111112111.content:
Kamper didn’t really need a dwelling inside Sparta, per say. If he needed rest, he went back to his own mountain/palace/castle. Mostly, he wandered around and observed Sparta. As with most societies, there were bits he didn’t like overly much. But, as a whole, he was content just observing.

Every once in a while he would interact and have fun with some of them. He had a few training sessions with the King and some of his elite men, who were still not clear why Kamper was afforded such respect and freedom. Only those that had come to see him in his palace figured it out, and didn’t spread it overly so. Last thing they wanted to do was anger him.

He liked that there were barely any actual sealed doors in the place. They just didn’t see the point he assumed. Anyone caught being somewhere they weren’t supposed to be were… otherwise motivated not to do so again, and others with that example. Therefore, Kamper had very little difficulty moving amongst peoples’ homes and whatnot. On this day, Kamper had entered the King’s home, easily snuck past the guards, and was observing him train his son. It was usually hard training, but that only produced the level of people that Kamper had now put a high value on.

Kamper watched for a while as the young boy tried to topple the giant of a warrior that was his father, with real swords of course. It took some time, but the King’s wife joined in watching from the opposite side and took even more time to notice Kamper. When she did, she walked forward to get her husband’s attention. That put a hold on his training session with his son, then his attention was on her, then on Kamper, which brought him forward now as well.

“Good morning, My King.” Kamper greeted as he entered the sandy area. The King eyed his son, then realized that trying to protect anyone against Kamper would be a fruitless pursuit if he really wanted to do them harm. So his eyes came back to Kamper, again thrown off by him showing him such respect.

“May I ask, My Lord, what you are doing in my home?” The King asked, trying to gauge Kamper’s intensions.

“I felt a good amount of potential and fighting spirit in here. I knew your aura, so I was interested in seeing who you were training with.” Kamper answered, then looked at the boy. “Very impressive. Such a scent, coming from someone so young.”

“Father? Who is this?” Asked the young boy, in a stance from his training, obviously unaware of whom he was referring to.

His wife had the same question and was more interested that her King of a husband hadn’t shown this intruder the door yet, in as aggressive a manner as his intrusion dictated. The King looked to Kamper, who nodded that it was ok to tell them, then again, Kamper hadn’t restricted the information that he was who he was. It was more an assumption on their part.

“My Lord, this is my son; Pleistarchus, and Wife; Gorgo of Sparta.” He introduced, then looked at his Wife and Son, then back at Kamper. “He is known as Kamper, also known as the Spartan Champion Titan; Death.”

At his words his wife gasped and his son dropped the sword he was holding. However, Kamper just glanced at it and it floated in midair just before hitting the ground. He raised it in front of the boy.

“Your blade shouldn’t taste the dirt unless you will it.” Kamper stated. The boy looked at the blade that just floated in front of him. He hesitantly reached out and grabbed it by the hilt to which Kamper let it go and let him hold it as he willed. He then looked to his wife and bowed a little. “Good to meet you, My Queen.”

“M-My Lord…” She said as she started to bow, to which the King stopped her. She looked at him as if he had just signed her death warrant.

“He has expressed that he doesn’t wish to be bowed to by any Spartan.” He explained, to which she straightened and nodded, then took an official stance.

Kamper thought about just leaving it at that, but he felt like their family deserved something more. So he, very slowly and careful to not effect too much, transformed into his normal Death form. He now stood a staggering 10 feet tall above them, his energy flapping his cloak around and causing wind to whip around the area, despite his efforts to the contrary. He held that form for a few minutes so the other two could soak it in, then reverted back to the sealed Kamper form, still in the same relaxed pose.

“You mind an extra body at your dinner table this evening?” Kamper asked.

“It would be an honor…” The Queen answered, still very nervous at the sudden realization that she had a Titan in her home. Not just any Titan either, but Spartan’s protector and the one that was rumored to cause the gods to quake in fear.
1553211122121111111112111.title: Meeting the King's family

15532111221211111111121112.content:
Kamper made quite an impression on the King and his family. That he was willing to just come by and spend time with them was something they were at first awestruck at, then valued highly. He showed both the King and his son some things in their training, but not enough to give them much more of advantage that Spartans already had normally.

Kamper was an enigma of sorts. Some knew who he was and knew not to treat him like his title would otherwise dictate. Others just knew him as one of the only non-Spartans that got to roam so freely that he was welcomed into the King’s home and could trounce a Spartan in battle. Kamper would go back to his castle every once in a while and socialize with a god or right a temple that was going too far. But, primarily, he stayed around Sparta. However, his journeys outside had shown him a threat that was closing in. Not to him, obviously, but to Greece and Sparta.

Soon after the initial confrontation and start of the war, a messenger came to Sparta and was shown the bottom of a well. He made it clear to the King that he was not there to fight their battles or decide their course. He was their protector from the realm beyond the realm of man. This war was for him and Sparta to decide. When he returned with news that they were not to go to war and you noticed that a few bribes were being exchanged, you decided that you would accompany him and his 300 ‘body guards’ as he called them, to the Hot Gates. So, he met them at the border.

“Looks like you are about to have some fun.” Kamper said as he leaned against a tree in their path. Leonidas smiled at this then nodded.

“Have you come to wish us luck, or perhaps…?” Leonidas started to ask, knowing full well Kamper’s ability and affinity for battle.

“I will be traveling with you, stretching my legs, as you will be… if you don’t mind that is?” Kamper asked. The King smiled at his apparent non-Titan like behavior. He, the Titan above gods and other Titans, was asking HIM for permission.

“If it is blood you seek, you are welcome to join us.” He answered with a broadening smile.

“Well then… we can get going then.” Kamper agreed, standing straight and clearly ready to travel. As he did so, the others, most of them, knew him as the man that trained with Spartans every once in a while. But some didn’t care to take part in the gossip. So they were curious and possibly a bit annoyed that their King just had a young man half some of their ages join, or looked have their ages at least.

“My King?” Asked their Captain.

“Yes?” Leonidas asked as they started walking and Kamper took position beside him to the right, while the Captain was stuck at his left.

“Who is this young man, or boy?” He asked.

“You’ll see, my friend.” The King responded with a smile to which Kamper joined in. This was a game for him then, perfect. Kamper humored him and shrugged to agree. All they would have to do is see him fight once to realize that he was anything besides normal. Soon the Acadians joined them as well, and they were on their way. One night, while Leonidas was sitting with Kamper, watching his men, another old man came by.

“So, you are planning on helping them then?” Asked the old man to Kamper.

“My Lord?” Leonidas asked, about to wake his men to surround the old man. Old or not, he was an intruder. But he didn’t know just who it was. So, Kamper just put a hand on his shoulder and shook his head. To this he sat and watched as the man settled in front of him.

“Just having a bit of fun. Help, would be a strong word, but I suppose I’ll be fighting at a lower level, so help works I guess.” Kamper answered.

“You don’t mind if we watch, do you?” The old man asked.

“That’s up to King Leonidas here… I’m part of his party, not the other way around.” Kamper answered then looked at Leonidas who was looking at him for an introduction at least. “My King, this is Zeus, in disguise of course. Zeus, this is King Leonidas, King of Sparta.”

“Zeus?!?” Leonidas asked, then looked at the old man. “Truly?”

“Yes, it is as he says. Now, do you mind, King of Sparta, if the gods watch your battle from Olympus?” Zeus asked, a bit irritated that he had to pay homage to a mortal King of all things. But it was worth it if it put him on Death’s good side.

“Yes, My Lord. Of course, do as you please.” Leonidas answered with a bow. Kamper was going to stop it but knew that it was the proper thing for him to do. Also, he was doing so out of respect and honor, not obligation.

“Within reason…” You added, to which both looked at him. “You may do as you wish, within reason. Sparta is still under my protection. I may be having fun, but don’t cross the line to enemy status.” Kamper warned.

“I wouldn’t think of it!” Zeus replied right away to wave any suspicion away. The last thing he wanted was Death coming after them.

“Very well.” Kamper stated.
15532111221211111111121112.title: Death and the mighty 300

155321112212111111111211121.content:
It was a relatively short trip and preparation to the battle. Kamper spent a considerable amount of time with Leonidas as the others did most of the work. He also watched the Persians with some intrigue, and was interested as to why they thought their king was a god of all things. He wasn’t even close to one, not even the form of those on Olympus. The other Spartans, particularly the Captain was a bit skeptical of him, but trusted in their king enough to not question his decision to have Kamper be with him all the time. Finally, the battle started and he watched as the 300 easily dispatched the soldiers thrown at them. It was beyond easy for the Spartans and the rest, including Kamper, could only watch. Finally, after Leonidas’s little meeting with their King, he came to ask something of Kamper.

“Well, looks like he took your bait.” Kamper said as he looked in the direction of the Persians’ camp.

“What do you mean?” Leonidas asked.

“Some specialty unit is starting to move around and form up at his command and anger. I got to say, young man, you never disappoint.” Kamper answered, then looked to him specifically. “You wanted to ask me something?”

“Yes, how would you like to ‘stretch your legs’ like you said?” Leonidas asked with a cautious smile.

“I could do with some entertainment. What do you have in mind?” Kamper asked plainly.

“Perhaps you being on standby in an area to give us Spartans a breath before we continue? I have a feeling that tonight will be rather interesting.” Leonidas asked and commented.

“That I agree. Remember, I will fight with you, but I won’t do anything overly crazy. If you make a decision that loses you this battle, I won’t just pick up the slack.” Kamper warned. He knew that Leonidas didn’t plan on losing, but Spartans weren’t exactly known for their retreating nature, quite the opposite actually. So, he thought it prudent to let him know, that if it came down to it, Kamper wouldn’t protect him beyond a certain point. After all, this was the affairs of men and he had his own life to live… and die.

“I understand, My Champion…” Leonidas answered, getting excited about seeing Kamper fight as well as his own fight to come.

“It has been quite entertaining to see you all have your fun. As I’ve thought, Spartans are a class of their own. Makes me very glad that I wanted to be a part of your kingdom.” Kamper complimented as he looked over to the other Spartans as they went around and celebrated their current success and prepared for the upcoming fighting.

“We definitely have had our fun, as you say. We do work hard at being the best warriors in the world… except you of course.” Leonidas agreed with pride at Kamper’s compliments to him and his country.

“That is hardly fair. I am a Titan, after all. I’m guessing that if you had access to my lifespan and immortality, you would be very comparable to my strength. Still, you’ve done very well as a mortal. Even if you were to die today, your family and people would still be ok, do in no small part to your leadership thus far.” Kamper returned with a bit of fondness. There were a few things that he didn’t like about Spartan society as a whole, but they were still his favorite in the end.

“True enough. Although, if I was immortal, I would still probably still fight and live the Spartan life, wither King or not.” Leonidas commented, insinuating that he really didn’t want to be immortal, even if it was an option for him. This made Kamper smile a little.

“Fair enough…” Kamper ended with, then continued to observe, waiting for the events to play out and have his part.
